title: ANZ summit call on extreme policy puts heat on Josh Frydenberg
text:
Having slashed the cash rate by a quarter-percentage-point three times since June to a record low 0.75 per cent - and likely to go even lower - the RBA is forced to contemplate the once-unthinkable - unconventional monetary policy, such as buying government bonds to push down long-term bond yields.

Elliott knows near-zero rates will squeeze the profit margins on bank loans and inevitably lead to more political rhetoric over banks not passing through the full dose of RBA rate cuts.

Banks may indeed be gouging their loyal home-loan customers by charging them higher rates than discounts offered to new customers, as Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) chairman Rod Sims and others have charged.

But that should not be conflated with the more justified withholding by banks of a portion of the central bank rate cuts, which is an entirely different matter.

About two-thirds of bank funding is sourced through deposits, not directly priced off the overnight cash rate.

As the RBA cash rate falls closer to zero, it is impractical for banks to drop already zero-interest deposit account rates into negative territory, so banks either need to suffer a collapse in their net interest margins or pocket some of the RBA rate cuts.

Intentionally or not, Elliott’s call puts a renewed focus on fiscal policy. The government is still steadfastly committed to achieving a budget surplus this financial year.

So fiscal and monetary policy are at loggerheads - with Canberra mildly tightening and Martin Place loosening.

Lowe has made clear he would prefer not to be easing rates to ultra-low levels or contemplating so-called quantitative easing (QE) - essentially done by the central bank artificially creating money to buy financial assets from private investors and pushing down bond yields.

Shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers has called on Frydenberg to heed Lowe’s pleas. Labor wants more spending on areas such as the Newstart unemployment allowance or rapid-fire infrastructure projects, while conveniently saying Frydenberg still doesn’t have to jeopardise a surplus given it is forecast to be $7 billion.

Frydenberg argues a surplus is a positive signal to investors, business and investors that the government is prudently managing its books and the economy.

He has signalled a willingness to consider a modest business investment tax break in the May budget next year.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison has suggested the budget could be recalibrated earlier in the December mid-year update if the economic circumstances warrant it.

But so far this mainly feels like Canberra fiddling around the edges.

Frydenberg must now fully answer if he would prefer the RBA to keep cutting rates towards zero and embark on QE, or if the better course of action would be an injection of fiscal stimulus to boost the economy in the short run and more structural reform in areas such as tax and competition policy to lift productivty in the medium term.

A summit of Treasury, RBA, financial regulators and bankers would provide an opportunity for a healthy debate on monetary and fiscal policy, so that’s why Frydenberg will run a million miles from Elliott’s suggestion.
description: ANZ chief Shayne Elliott’s call for an economic summit to look at the effect of ultra-low interest rates puts the spotlight on government policy levers.
